channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Is Preparing to Launch Another Long-Range Rocket
item.description: North Korea said Saturday that it would try to launch another long-range rocket later this month, a move that is likely to heighten already strained tensions with Washington and its allies.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Dividing the West Bank, Deepening a Rift
item.description: Construction on E1, in West Bank territory that Israel captured in the 1967 war, would connect the large Jewish settlement of Maale Adumim to Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A point in East Jerusalem overlooking a region to the left called E1, where Israel plans to build.

item.title: In Damascus, Tense Anticipation of Strongest Push Yet by Rebels
item.description: Clashes in the suburbs of Syria’s capital were accompanied by reports that President Bashar al-Assad was readying loyal divisions to defend the heart of his power.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Distant explosions have awakened a sense of foreboding even in the tranquil Old City.

item.title: Flow of Arms to Syria Through Iraq Persists, to U.S. Dismay
item.description: Iraqi airspace has emerged as a main supply route for weapons from Iran, which has an enormous stake in Syria, at a critical time for President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, ERIC SCHMITT and TIM ARANGO.
item.media:credit: Iraqi Civil Aviation Authority, via Reuters
item.media:description: An Iranian cargo plane during an inspection at Baghdad’s airport in October. Iraq has been reluctant to do inspections.

item.title: Alarm as China Issues Rules for Disputed Area
item.description: New rules announced last week to allow interceptions of ships in the South China Sea are raising concerns in the region, and in Washington, that simmering disputes with Southeast Asian countries over the waters will escalate.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Fishing boats off Vietnam’s coast in the South China Sea. One Chinese official said the new rules applied to disputed islands, too.

item.title: Effort to Secure Border Crimps Commerce Along It
item.description: An imposing wall of corrugated steel disconnects main streets, businesses, shared histories and binational family ties along the Mexican border in Arizona.
item.dc:creator: By FERNANDA SANTOS
item.media:credit: Samantha Sais for The New York Times
item.media:description: On the north side, Douglas, Ariz., businesses have struggled or failed, particularly since the American government stopped issuing visas in Agua Prieta about two years ago.

item.title: Amid Egypt’s Duel on Democracy, Morsi Calls for Vote
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi, whose recent tone and actions have reminded critics of his autocratic predecessor, set a referendum on a new constitution for Dec. 15.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Cairo rally for President Mohamed Morsi, who wants expanded powers, drew a crowd of hundreds of thousands on Saturday.

item.title: Economic Frustration Simmers Again in Tunisia
item.description: Since President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali was ousted in January 2011, the unemployment rate in Tunisia has risen to 18 percent from 13 percent, meaning some 750,000 people are out of work.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Tunis and across the country are struggling with high unemployment and inflation.

item.title: News Analysis: How Capitalist Are the Cubans?
item.description: Cuba seems to be sputtering, but not roaring, toward capitalism.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: A market sells dresses and other items in Havana.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Christmas Tree Controversy Fires Multicultural Belgium
item.description: Belgian traditionalists are up in arms over a decision to replace the annual Christmas tree in the main square of Brussels with a structure of steel-framed cubes. But the controversy has also stirred some racist reactions with an undercurrent of Islamophobia.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Brussels' steel-ribbed installation lit up the Grand Place on Thursday night.

item.title: With Aid, Afghan ‘Honor’ Victim Inches Back
item.description: “Honor killings” of women in Afghanistan are firmly anchored by Pashtunwali, an ages-old tribal code in the ethnic Pashtun areas of the country.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gul Meena, who was reportedly attacked by her brother for dishonoring their family, recovering at a hospital in Jalalabad.

item.title: Mayan ‘End of World’ Stirs Panic in Russia and Elsewhere
item.description: As rumors of an impending apocalypse stir anxiety in Russia, a nation with a penchant for mystical thinking, members of the government there have intervened in an attempt to quell the panic.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: John McAfee Plays Hide-and-Seek in Belize
item.description: Sought by the police in Belize as a “person of interest” in the investigation of a neighbor’s murder, the tech legend John McAfee has moved his noisy life underground.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Enrique Peña Nieto Takes Office as Mexico’s President
item.description: Enrique Peña Nieto has promised to accelerate economic growth, reduce the violence of the drug war and forge closer, broader ties with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: Enrique Peña Nieto, center, meeting with lawmakers at the national palace of Mexico on Saturday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Longest Season Really Is Over
item.description: 2012 was a marathon for those of us following the race. It took its toll. And just when it seemed it was over, a mini-controversy arose.
item.dc:creator: By BRAD SPURGEON
item.media:description: The start of the final race in the 2012 season, last weekend at the Interlagos circuit in Brazil. The showdown ended with Sebastian Vettel beating Fernando Alonso to the world drivers' title.

item.title: Congo Rebels Pulling Out of Goma
item.description: The M23 rebel group pulled hundreds of soldiers out of Goma, but many of the city’s residents said they feared the return of the government’s forces, who have a reputation for lawless behavior.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: M23 rebels loaded into trucks as they withdrew from Goma on Saturday.

item.title: Opinion: In Brazil, Poverty Is Deadly for Police Officers
item.description: In many Latin American cities, poorly paid police officers often live cheek by jowl with criminals. When violence erupts, low-level officers are easy targets.
item.dc:creator: By GRAHAM DENYER WILLIS
item.media:description: Brazilian mounted military police officers patrolled the streets in a shantytown in São Paulo, Brazil, last month.

item.title: After Death of Sattar Beheshti, Iranian Blogger, Head of Tehran’s Cybercrimes Unit Is Fired
item.description: The dismissal of the commander, Gen. Saeed Shokrian, follows investigations by Parliament and Iran’s judiciary into the unexplained death of the blogger, Sattar Beheshti.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Off the Shelf: ‘Exposure,’ the Story of a British Whistle-Blower in Japan
item.description: In “Exposure,” a new book, the former chief of Olympus of Japan tells how he became a whistle-blower after finding that the company was making questionable, money-losing acquisitions.
item.dc:creator: By BRYAN BURROUGH

item.title: Economic View: Euro Zone Keeps Playing a Dangerous Game
item.description: Although a potential solution to the euro zone’s crisis is apparent, governments keep playing a dangerous game of chicken.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER COWEN

item.title: South Africa Corruption Fuels Battle for Political Spoils
item.description: Dozens of officials, including ward councilors, party leaders and mayors, have been killed in what has become a desperate, deadly struggle for power and its spoils.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: Mariella Furrer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sizakele Malunga’s son, Dumisani Malunga, was killed over a council seat in KwaZulu-Natal.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Mazarine Pingeot, Mitterrand Daughter, Looks Back
item.description: Mazarine Pingeot, the daughter of François Mitterrand and Anne Pingeot, his longtime mistress, has written a diary that includes her memories of Mr. Mitterrand as an attentive and doting father.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: "Being unable to share a secret makes this secret very heavy. You protect it rather than protecting yourself."

item.title: Israel Moves to Expand Settlements in East Jerusalem
item.description: Two settlement actions seemed timed to punish the Palestinians for securing upgraded status at the United Nations, and appeared to show that hard-liners had prevailed in the debate over a response.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: A worker at a construction site in the West Bank Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, near Jerusalem, in June. Israel plans to link the settlement with Jerusalem.

item.title: Syria Rebels Find Skype Useful, but Dangers Lurk
item.description: Using satellite technology, much of it smuggled in, activists are still communicating online during an Internet blackout that started Thursday, but the government is finding ways to listen.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK

item.title: North Korea Says It Will Test Long-Range Rocket in December
item.description: The country said it will hold the launch between Dec. 10 and Dec. 22, a move likely to heighten already strained tensions with Washington and Seoul ahead of a South Korean presidential election on Dec. 19.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
